frontmatter.description: Helen Kennedy is Professor of Digital Society at the University of Sheffield. Her research traverses digital landscapes. She is especially interested in the datafication of everyday life.
frontmatter.title: Simple data visualisations have become key to communicating about the COVID-19 pandemic, but we know little about their impact.

frontmatter.description: Colin Angus recently demonstrated various visualisations that he had created for Covid-19 mortality on Twitter. Here he elaborates on his approach to this work.
frontmatter.title: Visualising high risk areas for Covid-19 mortality

frontmatter.description: A selection of visualisation templates for you to build a visualisation more quickly.
frontmatter.title: Visualisation templates for Python

frontmatter.description: A simple framework to get you started creating your own Shiny app
frontmatter.title: Template for Shiny applications

frontmatter.description: It is exciting to see your beautiful dash app running locally, but it would be even more interesting if  others can interact it over the web too!
frontmatter.title: Deploy Your Dash App

frontmatter.description: The Jupyter Notebook has become a very popluar web application for sharing and creating documents  that contain live code, equations, visualisations and narrative text. This article put together a  number of user-friendly pathways for running live, interactive Jupyter notebooks on the web, and  documentation on how to use it.
frontmatter.title: Hosting Jupyter Notebook

frontmatter.description: Based on the post - 'Plots wth Python', using IPython's widgets for exploring code and UK accidents dataset interactively.
frontmatter.title: Interactive Notebook with Jupyter Widgets

frontmatter.description: Dash apps are built with two parts - 'layout' and 'interactive'. To help us understand these two parts, let's build a dash app step by step and explore  useful documentations around them.
frontmatter.title: Dash: Layout and interactive

name.text: Open Access at The University of Sheffield (Tuesday)

description.text:
International Open Access Week is 20-26 October 2014.
Are you a researcher interested in submitting your publications to REF2020?  Have you heard about the new HEFCE open access policy?  Have you ever wondered what White Rose Research Online can do for you?  If the answer to any of these questions is yes, then come along to this session on Tuesday 21st October.  Open Access Coordinator Carmen O'Dell will give a short presentation covering the basic concepts of open access, funder requirements, and the implications for researchers. There will also be lots of time available for discussion and questions, so please come along to find out what you need to do and how the Open Access team can help.
description.html:
International Open Access Week is 20-26 October 2014.

Are you a researcher interested in submitting your publications to REF2020?

Have you heard about the new HEFCE open access policy?

Have you ever wondered what White Rose Research Online can do for you?

If the answer to any of these questions is yes, then come along to this session on Tuesday 21st October. 

Open Access Coordinator Carmen O'Dell will give a short presentation covering the basic concepts of open access, funder requirements, and the implications for researchers. There will also be lots of time available for discussion and questions, so please come along to find out what you need to do and how the Open Access team can help.
